setup.title: Simulation Mission Setup
setup.missionDesc: You are assigned to conduct a radiation survey at a facility. Your main task is to measure the dose rate at designated locations (marked with special boxes in the simulation). Use knowledge from the briefing materials to keep your total dose received as low as possible.
setup.missionDesc2: Configure the simulation parameters below to begin.

safety.safe: SAFE: Dose rate below safety limit.
safety.warning: WARNING: Dose rate is quite high.
safety.danger: DANGER: Dose rate is very high.
safety.tooClose: DANGER: You are too close to the radiation source. Move away immediately!

tooltips.containerDesc: Storage for radiation sources. This container can shield radiation from reaching the environment or human body. This is because it is made of lead, which has high density. This container can store radiation sources both in laboratory or industrial scale.
tooltips.shieldingDesc: Radiation shield to block radiation emission
tooltips.effectivenessDesc: Reduces radiation based on Beer-Lambert law

veryLow.description: The dose you received is very low, equivalent to or even lower than the dose received from eating one banana (which contains Potassium-40).
veryLow.effects: No detectable health effects. Far below safety limits.

low.description: Equivalent to the dose from several intercontinental flights or several dental X-rays.
low.effects: Health risks at this level are considered negligible and statistically undetectable.

moderate.description: You have received a dose equivalent to several CT scan procedures. This is still within the range of annual background radiation variation in different parts of the world.
moderate.effects: Stochastic risk (e.g., cancer) slightly increases, but is very difficult to distinguish from general population risk. The annual dose limit for the general public is 1000 ÂµSv (1 mSv).

high.description: This dose is above the annual limit for the general public. Radiation workers have higher limits (average 20,000 ÂµSv per year).
high.effects: Statistically measurable increase in cancer risk if such exposure occurs repeatedly. No deterministic effects (nausea, skin redness) will appear.

veryHigh.description: You have received a significant dose. This level requires monitoring and further evaluation in a real scenario.
veryHigh.effects: Long-term (stochastic) risk increases significantly. The higher the dose, the greater the risk. Approaching levels where early deterministic effects (such as blood changes) may begin to be detected in sensitive individuals.
